**Registraduría Begins Technical Simulations for March 8, 2026, Elections: What Will Be Tested?**
The National Registry of Civil Status (Registraduría Nacional del Estado Civil) will begin technical simulations for the March 8, 2026, legislative elections in Colombia, which will determine members of the Senate, the Chamber of Representatives, and presidential candidates from registered parties. The first simulation will take place on Saturday, February 7, 2026, testing pre-counting of votes. The second simulation is scheduled for February 21, followed by a comprehensive test of the election tallying process from February 23 to 25. The final simulation on February 26 will focus on the digitalization of the E-14 form. These tests will evaluate software, equipment, communications, cybersecurity, human resources, and logistics. The Registraduría has invited oversight bodies such as the Procuraduría and Contraloría, external auditors, political parties, and electoral observation organizations to participate. Registrador Hernán Penagos emphasized that the simulations aim to test both technological and human resources to ensure transparency and speed in result delivery. The legislative elections will be held on March 8, 2026, with the first round of the presidential election on May 31, and a potential second round on June 21, 2026.

**Colombia 2026 Elections: When and How to Vote from Abroad**
The National Registry of the Civil State (Registraduría Nacional del Estado Civil) has finalized the calendar and logistics for Colombian citizens living abroad to participate in the 2026 elections. Eligible voters registered at consulates may vote in inter-party consultations, Senate elections, the international constituency election for the Chamber of Representatives, and the first round of the presidential election. Voting for legislative elections and inter-party consultations will take place from March 2 to March 8, while presidential voting abroad will occur from May 25 to May 31. The Registraduría confirmed that Colombian residents abroad can vote for the Senate, and for one representative in the Chamber of Representatives from the international constituency. They may also participate in inter-party consultations, such as the Gran Consulta por Colombia and the Pacto Amplio, used to select presidential candidates. A facial biometrics tool has been implemented to enable remote identity verification for electoral services, including data updates and digital platform validation. According to official data, 1,096,368 Colombians living abroad are registered in the electoral census. To vote, citizens must have their ID registered at a consulate, which grants them national electoral eligibility. In 2022, the Registraduría operated 250 voting stations across 67 countries, with 1,343 polling places established at consulates and diplomatic missions—this framework will serve as the foundation for 2026. Although turnout abroad has historically been lower than the number of registered voters, their votes remain highly significant, especially in inter-party consultations, Senate elections, and a potential presidential race decided by narrow margins. With extended voting days, consular presence, and over one million eligible voters, the overseas vote is once again a key component of Colombia’s 2026 electoral process.

**Have You Registered Your ID? How to Secure Your Vote in Colombia’s 2026 Elections**
The registration of the Colombian national ID (cédula) is the essential first step for citizens wishing to participate in the 2026 congressional and presidential elections in Colombia. Both the National Registry of Civil Status (Registraduría) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Cancillería) have established a nationwide and international infrastructure to allow citizens to register or update their voting location. This includes hundreds of physical registration points and special days at high-traffic locations such as shopping centers and public transport hubs, operating from Monday to Saturday until March 31, 2026. In Bogotá, coordination with the TransMilenio transport system enhances access during key days. The process is free and requires either a physical cédula with holograms or a digital version, ensuring secure and modern electoral identification. Registration is required only for those who have changed residence, returned permanently to Colombia, or obtained their cédula before 1988 without joining the electoral census. Citizens can verify their current voting location online via the official Registraduría website. The Consular Registration for voting abroad is separate from other consular records and must be completed at embassies or consulates up to two months before each election. Once completed, re-registration is not needed. The registration period is final and no changes are allowed after the elections, ensuring electoral order, efficiency, and transparency, in line with Constitutional and legal frameworks such as Resolution 2580 of March 5, 2025. Key dates in the 2026 electoral calendar include the deadline for citizen registration (March 31, 2026), campaign periods, the start of overseas voting on May 25, the presidential election on May 31, and the subsequent scrutiny phase. Authorities stress that timely registration ensures voting at a nearby location and strengthens the legitimacy of democratic outcomes. Failure to register after moving may result in being assigned to a previous voting location, potentially requiring long-distance travel or even disqualification on election day. The Registraduría and Cancillería emphasize the importance of informed civic participation and timely updates to prevent logistical issues and ensure effective exercise of the right to vote.

**Registraduría’s Digital Strategy Aims to Boost Overseas Colombian Voter Influence in 2026 Elections**
The Registraduría Nacional de Colombia aims to increase the political influence of Colombian citizens abroad in the 2026 elections by simplifying the voting registration process. Historically, overseas voting has had low participation: in the 2022 elections, only 138,000 voted for the Senate and 306,000 for the presidency, despite 1,096,368 eligible voters abroad. The Registraduría estimates that approximately 4.7 million Colombians live abroad—nearly double the population of Medellín. To overcome barriers like the need to visit consulates in person, the Registraduría launched a digital platform allowing citizens abroad to update their voting location in 7–8 minutes. The process involves scanning a QR code, entering personal data, and completing facial biometric authentication via smartphone. Data is verified by the Registraduría’s Cybersecurity Center to prevent fraud. Results are sent via email. The system is only accessible from outside Colombia. As of the article’s publication, 56,000 users had successfully changed their voting location. The deadline to vote in both congressional and presidential elections is January 8, 2026; those applying between January 8 and March 31, 2026, can only vote in the presidential election. According to the Registraduría, this initiative seeks to break the historical pattern of low overseas voter turnout.

Based on comprehensive reporting from late February 2026, Colombia's National Registry of Civil Status (Registraduría Nacional del Estado Civil) has finalized extensive logistical preparations for the national legislative elections scheduled for **Sunday, March 8, 2026** [3][10][17]. Here is a detailed breakdown of the election logistics:

## Electoral Census and Infrastructure

The Registraduría has established a record electoral census of **41,287,084 eligible voters**, comprising 21,236,349 women and 20,050,735 men [14]. This includes:
- **40,036,238 domestic voters** assigned to **125,259 voting tables** across **13,493 polling stations** (6,011 urban and 7,482 rural locations) [12][14]
- **1,250,846 voters abroad** (683,287 women and 567,559 men) voting at **253 polling stations** in **67 countries** from March 2-8 [14]
- **1,438,986 citizens** in conflict-affected areas (19 departments, 168 municipalities) voting through **5,042 polling stations** in 16 Special Transitory Peace Circumscriptions (Citrep) [14]

The logistical operation involves **860,000 election jurors** and **9,300 judges** who will conduct final scrutiny and result declarations [11][13].

## Security and Risk Management

The government has implemented "Plan Democracia" with substantial security deployment:
- **50,000 personnel** from the military, police, and navy, plus nearly **500 armored vehicles** [13]
- **208 municipalities** (13% of the country) identified as high-risk based on 39 security variables, requiring prioritized protection [13][19]
- Seven prioritized municipalities in Antioquia (Ituango, Briceño, San Andrés de Cuerquia, Toledo, Andes, Betulia, Buriticá) receiving full military presence with drones and intelligence support [4]
- Financial rewards up to **50 million pesos** for reporting electoral crimes [13]
- Security details assigned to over **370 congressional candidates** and **64 presidential candidates** [13]

The Registraduría confirmed **no polling station relocations** are planned due to public order concerns, maintaining all 13,493 originally designated locations [13][15].

## Technology and Transparency Systems

The Registraduría has implemented multi-layered technological safeguards:
- **Source code auditing**: The complete source code for vote counting, pre-counting, jury selection, and dissemination systems has been made available to political party auditors, international observers (European Union, OAS, Carter Center), and oversight bodies in dedicated audit rooms [1][2][9][18]
- **Software "freezing"**: A cryptographic hash code system ensures the audited software version matches the election day version, with code freezing scheduled for the eve of the election [9][11]
- **E-14 digitization**: Double data entry processes and automated validation protocols (DIVIPOLE confirmation, transmission codes) minimize errors in result transmission from polling stations [1][2]
- **Biometric verification**: Facial and fingerprint recognition systems deployed to prevent identity fraud [7][11]
- **Digital ID acceptance**: Voters may use either traditional physical cédulas or digital IDs verified through facial recognition and dynamic holograms [7]

The CAPEL international institute is conducting parallel audits of pre-counting and consolidation systems to ensure international standards [18].

## Voting Day Logistics

**Operating Hours**: Polls open 8:00 a.m. and close 4:00 p.m. sharp (late arrivals cannot vote even if in line) [3][6].

**Voter Verification**: Citizens must verify their assigned polling station via www.registraduria.gov.co using their cédula number [3][6][10]. Voting locations include strategic sites such as shopping centers, terminals, and municipal buildings—Medellín alone has 18 designated registration and verification centers including El Tesoro, Unicentro, and San Diego malls [12].

**Ballot System**: Color-coded ballots prevent confusion:
- Blue: National Circumscription Senate
- Pink: Indigenous Special Circumscription Senate  
- Brown: Territorial Circumscription Chamber of Representatives
- Green: Indigenous Communities (Chamber)
- Gray: Afrodescendant Communities (Chamber) [5][6]

Voters receive up to three ballots (Senate, Chamber, and presidential primary consultation), but marking more than one option per race invalidates the vote [5][6].

**Restrictions**: Mobile phones are prohibited inside voting booths from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. [5][6]. A "dry law" (Ley Seca) prohibits alcohol sales from 6:00 p.m. March 7 through 6:00 a.m. March 9 [8].

## Special Administrative Measures

The Registraduría has made specific location adjustments to improve accessibility. In Cartagena, for example, the Corporación Minuto de Dios voting point was deactivated and its 865,352 registered voters redirected to the Institución Educativa San Lucas, while 12 new voting centers were activated citywide to reduce abstention [16].

For citizens abroad, registration remains open until March 31, 2026, for the presidential elections (though the deadline passed January 8 for legislative elections) [12]. Overseas voting begins May 25, 2026, for the presidential first round [17].

## Institutional Coordination and Recent Developments

Following questions from Interior Minister Armando Benedetti regarding electoral integrity, the Registraduría issued comprehensive responses on February 28, 2026, confirming that party auditors receive flat files with table-by-table vote data after each bulletin, and that the E-14 physical forms maintain full legal validity as "the physical proof of what the jury said" [1][2][8][15].

The "Colombia se Viste de Paz Electoral" campaign was launched February 26, 2026, by the Procuraduría, Registraduría, and Contraloría to combat disinformation and ensure respect for results [11].
